p: Piperine exhibited its antitumor effects by inhibiting HER2 mRNA expression l in HER2-overexpressing breast carcinoma cell lines [ 323]. In piperine-treated cells, apoptotic cell death increased by caspase-3 activation and PARP cleavage. Piperine also reduced cell migration by interfering with several signaling pathways including Akt, ERK1/2 and p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK). Piperine demonstrated similar effects on vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) found within blood vessels by inducing arrest at cell cycle and suppressing the activation of the MAPK through phosphorylation [ 324]. It reduced the BB and platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)-induced uncontrolled cell proliferation by changing the expression of p27 Kip1, cell cycle proteins including cyclin E, cyclin D and PCNA.
